The description of a lesion with glands and cysts in the upper lobe of the right lung is consistent with a congenital pulmonary airway malformation (CPAM). Surgery is the preferred treatment, and lobectomy is the standard of care. Antibiotics may be used to treat infections but will not address the underlying condition. Bronchoscopy may be useful in diagnosis but is not a treatment. Pneumonectomy is not necessary and may lead to significant functional impairment.

The presence of a lesion consisting of glands and cysts in the upper lobe of the right lung raises suspicion of congenital pulmonary airway malformation (CPAM). Lobectomy is the treatment of choice for symptomatic CPAM, and is often recommended in cases where the lesion is >2 cm or has recurred after resection. Antibiotics may be used for treatment of infections, but do not address the underlying condition. Bronchoscopy and pneumonectomy are not indicated for this condition.

The X-ray findings suggests that the child has a pulmonary sequestration, a condition where the lung tissue lacks normal communication with the tracheobronchial tree and produces recurrent infections. Surgery is the most effective management for this condition, and the most appropriate surgical option is lobectomy to remove the affected lobe of the lung. Antibiotics may be useful in treating infections, but they do not treat the underlying condition. Bronchoscopy and pneumonectomy are not appropriate for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lesion in the right upper lobe of the lung suggests a possible congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation (CCAM). Lobectomy is the treatment of choice for CCAM in children, as it removes the cysts and glandular tissue and minimizes the risk of infection and malignant transformation. Antibiotics may be used to treat infections associated with CCAM, but it does not treat the underlying condition. Bronchoscopy or pneumonectomy are not indicated in this case.
